title: â€˜Stranger Things 5â€™ Becomes Netflixâ€™s No. 9 Most Popular English-Language Series of All Time With 105.7 Million Views So Far
description: Season 5 of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ joined Netflixâ€˜s list of its most popular English-language TV titles of all time immediately after becoming eligible w
body:
Season 5 of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ joined Netflixâ€˜s list of its most popular English-language TV titles of all time immediately after becoming eligible with the release of the series finale on New Yearâ€™s Eve.

	As a whole, the season has reached 105.7 million views so far. Netflix compiles its all-time list by counting views across each titleâ€™s first 91 days of viewing; for batched releases like â€œStranger Things,â€ views are counted through each volumeâ€™s first 91 days. As such, because Volume 1 of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ Season 5 debuted on Nov. 26, those four episodes will continue to accrue chart viewership through Feb. 24, while Volume 2â€™s three episodes will be counted from Dec. 25 to March 25 and finale viewership will count from Dec. 31 to March 31.
	



	

	



	Therefore, â€œStranger Thingsâ€ Season 5 has three months to continue climbing higher on the all-time chart. With its current spot as No. 9, it knocked â€œFool Me Onceâ€ off the chart and surpassed Season 1 of â€œThe Night Agent.â€ Season 4 of â€œStranger Things,â€ which was released in 2022, remains No. 3 on the chart to this day (140.7 million), outranked only by â€œWednesdayâ€ Season 1 (252.1 million views) and â€œAdolescenceâ€ (142.6 million). Given that â€œStranger Thingsâ€ Season 5 achieved with Netflixâ€™s biggest-ever opening for an English-language series with 59.6 million views, it seems possible that the sci-fi seriesâ€™ final entry could make it to No. 1.


	Naturally, â€œStranger Thingsâ€ Season 5 was the most-watched title of the week Dec. 29-Jan. 4, during with the finale was available for five days, hitting 31.5 million views overall. While Netflix did not provide a viewership total for the finale alone, it should be noted that the weekly total would have been even higher if not for Netflixâ€™s decision to concurrently debut the finale in movie theaters, where it earned more than $25 million.
	

	Additionally, all previous seasons of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ continued to chart for the sixth week in a row: Season 1 ranked at No. 3 with 7.6 million views, Season 2 was No. 5 with 5.5 million, Season 3 was No. 7 with 5 million and Season 4 was No. 8 with 4.8 million.

	Besides â€œStranger Things,â€ the Netflix Top 10 for Dec. 29-Jan. 4 featured Harlan Cobenâ€™s â€œRun Away,â€ which debuted at No. 2 with 12.7 million views in its first four days of availability. Season 5 of â€œEmily in Parisâ€ ranked at No. 4 with 7.4 million views in its third week on the chat. At No. 6 was the Ricky Gervais special â€œMortality,â€ which debuted with 5.1 million views in six days. â€œMan vs. Babyâ€ had its fourth week on the chart at No. 9 with 4 million views and was followed by â€œDave Chappelle: The Unstoppableâ€¦â€ at No. 10 with 2.8 million views. 

	See the Netflix Top 10 for Dec. 29-Jan. 4 below, beginning with English-language shows and movies and followed by non-English-language shows and movies.

schema.headline: â€˜Stranger Things 5â€™ Becomes Netflixâ€™s No. 9 Most Popular English-Language Series of All Time With 105.7 Million Views So Far

title: Kristen Stewart Teases Jesse Eisenberg for Watching Her Movie on a Laptop as They Break Down How Directing Changes Their Acting: â€˜I Get Mad at People Now for Cuttingâ€™
description: â€œI swear to God. Iâ€™m going to kill myself,â€ Kristen Stewart says, ribbing her longtime friend Jesse Eisenberg for watching her directorial debut, â€œT
body:
â€œI swear to God. Iâ€™m going to kill myself,â€ Kristen Stewart says, ribbing her longtime friend Jesse Eisenberg for watching her directorial debut, â€œThe Chronology of Water,â€ on his laptop. Â 

	The â€œTwilightâ€ star, who earned an Oscar nomination for portraying Princess Diana in â€œSpencer,â€ vowed to quit acting until she could adapt Lidia Yuknavitchâ€™s 2011 stream-of-conscious memoir about a young woman (played by Imogen Poots), sexually abused as a child, who eventually finds her voice through writing and swimming. Stewart didnâ€™t labor for nearly a decade to secure the filmâ€™s financing only for someone to see her passion project on a computer screen. Â 
	

	â€œItâ€™s supposed to be a sonic experience,â€ she sighs and keeps roasting Eisenberg. â€œYou know about movies? Have you ever made a movie?â€Â 

	Stewart and Eisenberg met on 2009â€™s coming-of-age comedy â€œAdventurelandâ€ and reunited on 2015â€™s stoner adventure â€œAmerican Ultraâ€ and Woody Allenâ€™s 2016 romantic drama â€œCafe Society.â€ Since then, Eisenberg has directed two films, 2022â€™s dramedy â€œWhen You Finish Saving the Worldâ€ and 2024â€™s Oscar-nominated â€œA Real Pain.â€ So yeah, he knows something about making movies, as well as a directorâ€™s desire for audiences to see them on the big screen.Â 

	â€œIâ€™m aware of that and was taking all of that into account,â€ Eisenberg wryly retorts before complimenting his pal. â€œI was astounded. Iâ€™ve never seen something made like this by someone I know who is also funny.â€Â 

	Stewart and Eisenberg continue to tease each other during their conversation, in which they discuss how directing has changed their perspective as actors and whether they care if their films make money. Â 
	

	Jesse Eisenberg: Are you OK?Â 

	Kristen Stewart: That should be the intro: â€œAre you OK?â€ Iâ€™m not kidding. Thatâ€™s often how we greet each other.Â 

	Eisenberg: Weâ€™ve known each other for a long time â€” 15 years, right?Â 

	Stewart: I was 17 when we met. Iâ€™m 35.Â 

	Eisenberg: Oh my God, really? I saw your movie 24 hours ago. I was blown away. My first thought was â€œWe can do that? I didnâ€™t know we could do that.â€ Itâ€™s unbelievably audacious. You read this book, but how did you convey it to other people? (I know these are junket questions.) What does the script look like? Â 

	Stewart: You and I are fairly shy people, but thereâ€™s an innate, stifling invisibility that women have to grapple with, even if they werenâ€™t abused by their father. I didnâ€™t want to make statements, like, â€œThis is what the movieâ€™s about.â€ There was just something about the book that spoke to the universality of being a young girl trying to excavate a voice thatâ€™s been told to shut up. Â 

	Eisenberg: You and I have the advantage of being known actors. It allows, or maybe gives, us the responsibility to make something thatâ€™s harder to convey. Is that part of the reason you were able to do something so abstract? The result is astounding, but thatâ€™s not guaranteed. Â 



	

									Benedict Evans for Variety
	



	Stewart: It wasnâ€™t easy for me to make the movie. It took eight years. People that love me were genuinely sick and tired of hearing me be so upset about it. And then those things are baked into the plot of the movie. Itâ€™s about the malleability of our realities. I had to continuously remind people that we were doing a poem.Â 

	Eisenberg: What I was asking before, if I can ask it better, is â€”Â 

	Stewart: I can answer it better.Â 

	Eisenberg: This is my question: Did you feel a responsibility to make something unusual because youâ€™re a well-known actor, or is this just entirely your taste?Â 

	Stewart: This is entirely my taste. I could never make something straightforward. I like associative, open-ended things that say something very particular but invite people to disagree. Â 

	Eisenberg: How did your taste develop?Â 

	Stewart: I donâ€™t like being told what to do. I donâ€™t want to tell people what to do.Â 
	

	Eisenberg: I read something you said, which I thought was funny and reminded me of myself. Somebody asked you, â€œDo you think of being an actor in a movie differently now?â€ Youâ€™re like, â€œOf course. Iâ€™ll go to the director and say, â€˜Iâ€™ll do whatever you want me to do.â€™â€ Â 

	Stewart: Iâ€™ll never question anything again. Iâ€™m like, â€œAnything you want.â€ The idea of being like, â€œYou should cast this person.â€ Iâ€™m like, â€œExcuse me? You donâ€™t know anything.â€Â 

	Eisenberg: Isnâ€™t that fascinating? A lot of people in our position go the other way. They feel even more like they need control because they have an experience where they were controlling everything. The story I always tell about you â€” because Iâ€™ve been asked about you for 18 years â€” is when we were doing â€œAdventureland,â€ there was a dramatic scene at night, and you were like, â€œCut. Iâ€™m lying.â€ You were 17, and I was shocked. I felt like I was watching a master. Would you have done that now?Â 

	Stewart: I get mad at people now for cutting, because Iâ€™m like, â€œI know you questioned yourself, but that moment of question was gold.â€ I want to try and not do that. [As an actor] I donâ€™t want to be misinterpreted. When a director is like, â€œIt seemed like you were feeling it.â€ I always say, â€œI donâ€™t care if it looks good; I want to do it again.â€ Iâ€™m selfish. I want to taste it. Â 



	

									Benedict Evans for Variety
	



	Eisenberg: â€œI want the catharsis.â€ One of the other stories I tell from â€œAdventurelandâ€ was a quick scene. I had my first panic attack on set; I was self-aware in the worst way, and I shut down. After the tape, I was mortified. Greg [Mottola, the director] goes, â€œI didnâ€™t notice, but Iâ€™m so sorry you felt that way.â€ He said, â€œI donâ€™t understand how actors arenâ€™t having panic attacks all the time. Youâ€™re in front of strangers, and you have to be vulnerable.â€ For years, I remember thinking, â€œItâ€™s a sweet thing he said, but heâ€™s pitying actors too much. Weâ€™re lucky. We have an easy job. We memorize lines.â€ Â 

	Now I have respect for the job in a way I never did personally. Because I was so self-critical, I couldnâ€™t have a good feeling about it. It seemed like, â€œYouâ€™re overpaying me.â€ Then Julianne Moore was in my movie, and after her first scene, I turned to my producer and was like, â€œCan we pay her more?â€ Did you have that feeling with Imogen? Iâ€™ve done three movies with her. But not in the same way Iâ€™ve done three movies with you. How did you choose her? Â 
	

	Stewart: Youâ€™re one of the reasons. I was like, â€œIâ€™m sure we would be close because you guys are friends.â€ She did an audition. She sent a tape and I was like, â€œOh my God.â€ Thereâ€™s somethingÂ  about her being 35 and me being 35. We should have been friends since we were younger. We just never met. Then we did, and it was the perfect time to go, â€œWe need to shove everything weâ€™ve never said to each other into this movie.â€Â 

	Eisenberg: Do you feel you could have this style and use it going forward?Â 

	Stewart: Iâ€™m always asked if I would continue to work as an actor in studio films, or if feels like youâ€™re selling a homogenized idea that doesnâ€™t land on an individual, necessarily, but satisfies a group? I wouldnâ€™t be good at that job. Â 

	Eisenberg What do you mean? To direct a more commercial thing?Â 

	Stewart: More and more, commercial means standard and digestible. I want to be allowed to make movies that allow for time to figure out a structure and mission statement. The next movie I want to make utilizes different formats. Not because itâ€™s nerdy film stuff, but because itâ€™s more interesting to make movies about how you see something instead of what you see.Â 

	Eisenberg: Your movie is coming out soon. Do you think or care about it making money? Â 

	Stewart: It would be great if it did because then maybe it wouldnâ€™t be as difficult to make my next movie. But at the same time, the next movie I want to make functions outside of the business structure weâ€™re used to. People love to hear that.Â 

	Eisenberg: â€œThis doesnâ€™t even exist in your structure.â€ Â 

	Stewart: Well, it doesnâ€™t. You need to find new terms for all of this because, Iâ€™m sorry, but the language and structure are oppressive. Â 

	Eisenberg: Thereâ€™s no English on this set. It doesnâ€™t apply to what weâ€™re doing.Â 

	Stewart: Actually, the title of the movie is in Spanish. Iâ€™m not going to tell you what it is.Â 

	Eisenberg: I wouldnâ€™t understand it.Â 

	Stewart: Yeah, youâ€™re just a dummy.Â 

	Eisenberg: So you care insofar as it helps you make the next one. You care insofar as it pays the people back who paid for it. But youâ€™re not caring about what other people might think about it? People ask me too. I guess I donâ€™t care about it being a successful business thing. My mind doesnâ€™t go there, or I canâ€™t conceive of it.Â 
	

	Stewart: For sure. I love the movie. I birthed it. I probably would have made this movie if I was never an actor. I didnâ€™t feel like I was graduating into like, â€œNow I want to check that box.â€ I think this thing needs to exist.Â 

	Eisenberg: Weâ€™re directing everything, but weâ€™re also desperate actors. So all Iâ€™ll say is this: I can learn Spanish for your next project.Â 

	Stewart: You need to put yourself on tape.Â

schema.headline: Kristen Stewart Teases Jesse Eisenberg for Watching Her Movie on a Laptop as They Break Down How Directing Changes Their Acting: â€˜I Get Mad at People Now for Cuttingâ€™

title: Skims' Team USA Olympics Collection Is Finally Here
description: Skims is going all in on sports in 2026 â€” starting with a continued partnership with Team USA ahead of the Winter Olympics, which kick off in Milan
body:
Skims is going all in on sports in 2026 â€” starting with a continued partnership with Team USA ahead of the Winter Olympics, which kick off in Milan on Feb. After high-profile collections tied to Tokyo 2020, Beijing 2022 and Paris 2024, the latest Skims for Team USA drop gives an athletic and patriotic refresh to the brandâ€™s bestselling silhouettes. 

	â€œItâ€™s truly an honor to continue this incredible partnership with Team USA,â€ Kim Kardashian, co-founder and CCO of Skims said in a statement. â€œThis collection celebrates the courage, determination and excellence of these incredible athletes, inspiring us to all push further, dream bigger, and embrace who we are. Iâ€™m proud that Skims can support and celebrate them as they go for the gold.â€


		

						
			
	

	
					
		

										LIMITED-EDITION 						

					Skims Team USA Collection 		

		
	

	The Winter 2026 campaign underscores that ambition, spotlighting a roster of Olympians and Paralympians across disciplines. The lineup includes Olympic gold medalist and three-time world ice dance champion Madison Chock, two-time Paralympian and world champion Nordic skier Dani Aravich and world champion bobsledder Kaysha Love. Shot by Hugh Wilson, the campaign leans into high-flash photography and graphic props inspired by the awards podiums used during the Olympic medal ceremonies. 

	For the athletes, the collection reflects the realities of life around competition. Chock said the pieces fit seamlessly into her routine, from training days to travel and recovery, while Aravich emphasized the importance of ease and inclusivity during long, demanding schedules. Love described the capsule as versatile essentials designed for real life, whether on the move or winding down during the Games.


	The Skims for Team USA capsule will be available in sizes XXS through 4X, with prices ranging from $20 to $88. The collection launches Jan. 8, 2026, at 9 a.m. PT / 12 p.m. ET on skims.com and in select Skims flagship stores in New York and Los Angeles.

	Shop a few of the best pieces from the collection below:

schema.headline: Skims' Team USA Olympics Collection Is Finally Here

title: Tiger Woodsâ€™ TGL Golf Season Opener Streams Live Online Today
description: TGLâ€™s second season kicks off today, with the leagueâ€™s first event of the year taking place at the SoFi Center in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The tech-
body:
TGLâ€™s second season kicks off today, with the leagueâ€™s first event of the year taking place at the SoFi Center in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The tech-forward, team-based league founded by Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy carved out a new lane in the golf calendar last year with its fast-paced, shot clock and made-for-TV format.

	The opening match of the 2026 TGL calendar features a high-stakes rematch between The Bay Golf Club and Atlanta Drive GC, revisiting one of last seasonâ€™s most consequential playoff moments. The Bay, represented by Wyndham Clark, Shane Lowry, Min Woo Lee and Ludvig Aberg, will be looking to avenge a playoff loss to Atlanta, whose lineup includes Justin Thomas, Patrick Cantlay, Lucas Glover and Billy Horschel. Last season, Atlanta eliminated The Bay 9-3 in the Semifinals, though The Bay secured a narrow 6-5 victory in regular-season play, setting up a compelling battle for the season opener.


	Channel: ESPNLive Stream: Hulu + Live TV, Fubo, Sling TV, DIRECTVStart Time: 5 p.m. ET
	
		How to Watch TGL Season Opener Online for Free	

	To watch TGLâ€™s first event of the year, youâ€™ll need access to ESPN, either through cable or a live TV streaming service like YouTube TV, Hulu + Live TV, Fubo, Sling TV, or DIRECTV Stream. ESPN+ alone wonâ€™t cut it â€” but there are multiple streaming options if youâ€™re watching without cable.

	ESPN is available on DIRECTV, which currently offers a five-day free trial for new subscribers. The service is also running a $49.99 first-month promotion on its base package, after which their standard pricing of $79.99 applies. 


	If you want an all-in-one streaming bundle, Hulu + Live TV carries ESPN along with a broad mix of sports, news, and entertainment channels. Plans start at $82.99 per month and include Huluâ€™s on-demand library, Disney+, and ESPN+. A 3-day free trial is available for new subscribers.

	The most budget-friendly way to watch ESPN live is through Sling TVâ€™s Orange plan. Pricing starts at $40 per month, and while Sling does not offer a free trial, it remains one of the lowest-cost options for live ESPN access without cable. You can get a 1-Day Pass for $4.99 if you want to stream the event without needing to commit to a full subscription. 

	Built with sports fans in mind, Fubo offers ESPN as part of its live TV packages. Plans begin at $79.99 per month, with support for streaming across smart TVs, mobile devices, and desktop browsers. Fubo offers a 7-day free trial for first-time subscribers.

schema.headline: Tiger Woodsâ€™ TGL Golf Season Opener Streams Live Online Today

title: LISTEN: Why Female Cinematographers are Poised for Triumph This Awards Season
description: On todayâ€™s episode of â€œDaily Varietyâ€ podcast, Jazz Tangcay, Varietyâ€™s senior artisans editor, explains why the stars have aligned and this film awa
body:
On todayâ€™s episode of â€œDaily Varietyâ€ podcast, Jazz Tangcay, Varietyâ€™s senior artisans editor, explains why the stars have aligned and this film award season has already marked a breakthrough moment for female cinematographers. 

	More to come

	(Pictured: Cinematographers Autumn Durald Arkapaw, Alice Brooks and Amy Vincent)

schema.headline: LISTEN: Why Female Cinematographers are Poised for Triumph This Awards Season

title: NBCU Says 2026 Winter Olympics Ads Have Sold Out
description:
Hereâ€™s one Olympic competition that is now closed to certain entrants.

	NBCUniversal said Tuesday that it has sold out of all the commercial invent
body:
Hereâ€™s one Olympic competition that is now closed to certain entrants.

	NBCUniversal said Tuesday that it has sold out of all the commercial inventory tied to its coming telecast of the 2026 Winter Olympics from Milan Cortina, offering the latest example of the growing dependence traditional media companies have on sports and live events. The ad-sales milestone comes after NBC has dispensed with all the ad time tied to its looming February broadcast of Super Bowl LX as well as the NBA All-Star Game. The three events boosted NBCUâ€™s status in last yearâ€™s â€œupfrontâ€ sales market.
	

	NBCU sold approximately $900 million in advertising tied to each of its most recent Winter Olympics efforts, the 2022 Games from Beijing and the 2018 spectacular from PyeongChang. The company said its Milan Winter Olympics had secured â€œtheÂ highest linear and digital revenue in Winter Olympics history,â€ without offering a specific number.


	â€œFor the first time in our companyâ€™s history, we have seen suchÂ unprecedentedÂ demand that we are officially sold out of our inventoryÂ this far inÂ advance of a Games,â€ said Peter Lazarus, executive vice president of NBC Sports &Â Olympics,Â Advertising and Partnerships, in a statement. â€œWe areÂ excited to once again deliver fans a word class viewingÂ experience;Â while providing brands the powerful haloÂ effect theÂ OlympicsÂ has to offer.â€Â Â 

	NBC had reason to focus on sports ad sales. The company had hundreds of hours of sports to sell last year, with a February that is crammed with Olympics telecasts, Super Bowl programming and NBA matches. More is on the way, with a new rights deal with Major League Baseball that will give NBC games to show on Sunday nights in the interim between its NBA and NFL deals.
	

	â€œWith the resurgence of the Olympic movement, our strongest Sports Upfront in history, the early sell out of Super Bowl LX,Â and theÂ remarkable return of the NBA,Â NBCUniversal has solidified itself as a sports powerhouse and brands have taken notice,â€ saidÂ Mark Marshall, chairman, globalÂ advertising & partnerships, NBCUniversal, in a statement.Â 

	NBCU is harnessing momentum from its recent Summer Olympics telecast from Paris. The event relied more heavily on bespoke streaming experiences, smart curation of events for broadcast primetime and lots of celebrity cameos. The company said more than 100 advertisers committing to the Winter Olympics were new to the event. Nearly 60 invested in unique elements tied to the Games and more than a dozen invested in sponsorships that will offer fans more live sports viewing.

schema.headline: NBCU Says 2026 Winter Olympics Ads Have Sold Out

title: Tracee Ellis Ross Enters Multi-Year Deal at Fox Entertainment Studios
description: Tracee Ellis Ross and her production company Joy Mill Entertainment have entered a multi-year deal at Fox Entertainment Studios. The partnership ent
body:
Tracee Ellis Ross and her production company Joy Mill Entertainment have entered a multi-year deal at Fox Entertainment Studios. The partnership entails a first-look deal for scripted content and an overall deal for unscripted content produced by Joy Mill.

	Joy Millâ€™s scripted slate will span across comedy, drama and animation, with unscripted and reality formats to be developed as well. Adriana Ambriz will continue her role as Joy Millâ€™s head of development, having entered the position in 2020.
	

	Ross is best known for starring as Dr. Rainbow Johnson in â€œBlack-ish,â€ the Kenya Barris-created sitcom that ran on ABC for eight seasons from 2014 to 2022. Before that, she led the Mara Brock Akil comedy â€œGirlfriendsâ€ as Joan Carol Clayton for eight seasons on UPN and later the CW. Her other prominent credits include the 2020 film â€œThe High Note,â€ which she executive produced in addition to starring, the 2023 film â€œAmerican Fictionâ€ and the Season 7 â€œBlack Mirrorâ€ episode â€œCommon People.â€ In 2022, Hulu and the Oprah Winfrey Network debuted â€œThe Hair Tales,â€ a docuseries Ross created about the history and significance of Black hair. She is also the founder of the hair care brand Pattern Beauty.


	Ross is repped byÂ Artists First,Â UTA, Origin Public Relations andÂ Hansen, Jacobson, Teller.

	â€œTracee is a singular force, creative, purposeful and culturally undeniable,â€ said Fox Entertainment Studiosâ€™ head of scripted, Hannah Pillemer, and head of unscripted, Allison Wallach. â€œHer instincts, curiosity and drive make her an exceptionally creative and prolific partner. Weâ€™re excited to team up with Tracee and Joy Mill Entertainment to create work that inspires, entertains and reflects the world through their distinctly authentic lens.â€
	

	â€œJoining the Fox Entertainment Studios family marks an exciting next chapter for Joy Mill Entertainment,â€ said Ross. â€œAt Joy Mill, our focus is in creating and producing entertaining, cultureÂ bending stories centered around identity and joy, and from our earliest conversations with Fox, it was clear that they shared the same vision. Iâ€™m excited to collaborate with Hannah, Allison, Fernando Szew, Tomii Crump and their incredible teams as we continue to expand our platform.â€

schema.headline: Tracee Ellis Ross Enters Multi-Year Deal at Fox Entertainment Studios

title: Ben Affleck Says â€˜Argoâ€™ Oscar Snub for Best Director Was â€˜Massive Embarrassmentâ€™
description: Ben Affleck appeared on â€œJimmy Kimmel Live!â€ amid his press tour for Netflixâ€™s â€œThe Ripâ€ and looked back on the â€œmassive embarrassmentâ€ of being snu
body:
Ben Affleck appeared on â€œJimmy Kimmel Live!â€ amid his press tour for Netflixâ€™s â€œThe Ripâ€ and looked back on the â€œmassive embarrassmentâ€ of being snubbed at the Oscars for best director with â€œArgo.â€ Affleck was a frontrunner to land a nom. He won best director honors at the Golden Globes, Critics Choice Awards and BAFTAs. Alas, Affleck was snubbed while â€œArgoâ€ went on to earn seven Oscar nominations and win best picture and two other prizes.
	

	â€œIt was the year, the horrible thing of everyone telling you, â€˜Youâ€™re gonna get nominated, youâ€™re gonna get nominated for director,â€™â€ Affleck remembered. â€œAnd so, of course, I wake up that morning, and sure enough â€” and, by the way, itâ€™s not [unlike] any other morning that I had not been nominated for best director. But all of a sudden, itâ€™s a massive embarrassment. I woke up and people [said], â€˜You didnâ€™t get nominated.â€™â€


	Affleckâ€™s story reminded Kimmel of being at the Critics Choice Awards the night prior, where â€œOnce Battle After Anotherâ€ picked up major honors for best picture, director and adapted screenplay but left leading man Leonardo DiCaprio shut out for best actor (which went to Timothee Chalamet for â€œMarty Supremeâ€).


	â€œI was thinking, boy, heâ€™s got so many better places to be,â€ Kimmel quipped about DiCaprio. â€œAnd the movie wins best picture. The directorÂ Paul Thomas AndersonÂ wins best director, and then he doesnâ€™t win. And Iâ€™m thinking he must be so pissed that [he had to leave] whatever he got airlifted from â€” a yacht somewhere â€”Â and couldnâ€™t be there anymore. He came to lose.â€
	

	â€œThis is maybe the worst award-show situation ever,â€ Kimmel continued. â€œI think youâ€™re underselling this. BecauseÂ â€˜Argo,â€™ not only was it nominated for the Oscar for best picture, youÂ wonÂ best picture. You starred in it and directed it, and you were not nominated in either category â€¦ itâ€™s as if the movie directed itself.â€

	â€œThatâ€™s sort of what it felt like,â€ Affleck replied. â€œThe day of the snub, which all of a sudden itâ€™s a negative event and a horrible thing, I had to go to the Critics Choice Awards. I remember getting there and thereâ€™s a red carpet line, like 500 people dying to talk to me, and every single one of them was like, â€˜Hi! So the snubâ€¦â€™ What do you say to that? â€˜Itâ€™s a bummer!â€™ I did end up winning the Critics Choice Award.â€

	â€œHonestly, itâ€™s just embarrassing,â€ Affleck added. â€œI wasnâ€™t the one going out there being like, â€œIâ€™m going to be nominated!â€™ Itâ€™s having to be put through the ritual of then answering for why you didnâ€™t get nominated. I didnâ€™t say I was [going to be]!â€

	Someone who can relate to what Affleck is talking about is Bradley Cooper, who was similarly snubbed for best director with â€œA Star Is Bornâ€ despite landing nominations from the Golden Globes, Criticsâ€™ Choice Awards and Directors Guild of America. Cooper also said the snub was â€œembarrassing.â€ 

	â€œThe first thing I felt was embarrassment, actually. Think about it. I felt embarrassed that I didnâ€™t do my part,â€ Cooper told Oprah in 2019. â€œEven if I got the nomination, it should not give me any sense of whether I did my job or not. Thatâ€™s the trick, to make something that you believe in.â€

	Cooper explained that did not set out to make a movie that landed Academy Award nominations, adding: â€œThe only thing I set out to do was to tap into as an authentic place as possible. [An authentic place] in myself and everybody I asked to make this movie â€” to tell a human story of people who are going to deal with their family life, trauma as a child, addiction in a real way, love in this life and finding your voice.â€

	Watch Affleckâ€™s full interview on â€œJimmy Kimmel Live!â€ in the video below.

schema.headline: Ben Affleck Says â€˜Argoâ€™ Oscar Snub for Best Director Was â€˜Massive Embarrassmentâ€™

title: Henry Winkler to Star in Legal Comedy â€˜Last Chance Lawyerâ€™ in Works at NBC
description:
Henry Winkler is attached to star in a legal comedy in development at NBC titled â€œLast Chance Lawyer.â€

	In the series, Winkler would play Howard Gr
body:
Henry Winkler is attached to star in a legal comedy in development at NBC titled â€œLast Chance Lawyer.â€

	In the series, Winkler would play Howard Greenberg, a hard-driving and unconventional criminal defense attorney who is a fierce advocate for his underdog clients. He believes â€œno matter what they are accused of, the system is always guiltier.â€ (Hereâ€™s hoping Howard is more competent than Barry Zuckerkorn, the attorney Winkler played on â€œArrested Development.â€)
	

	â€œLast Chance Lawyerâ€ is written by Mike Gagerman and Andrew Waller, who executive produce alongside Winkler, Jed Mercurio and Jimmy Mulville via Hat Trick Media. Universal Television, a division of Universal Studio Group, is the studio behind the project.


	Winkler is best known for embodying the leather jacket-wearing 1970s and â€™80s icon Arthur Fonzarelli, aka the Fonz, on the ABC sitcom â€œHappy Days.â€ He recently starred opposite Bill Hader on the HBO dark comedy â€œBarry,â€ for which Winkler won his first Primetime Emmy, for best supporting actor in a comedy. As mentioned above, he also had a kooky recurring role on â€œArrested Development,â€ and he had memorable roles opposite Adam Sandler in â€œThe Waterboyâ€ and â€œClick.â€ He recently starred in the crime thriller â€œNormalâ€ opposite Bob Odenkirk, and his additional credits include â€œNight Shift,â€ â€œHere Comes the Boom,â€Â â€œHeroes,â€ â€œHolesâ€ and â€œScream.â€ Next up, heâ€™ll be seen in the music festival comedy â€œRolling Loud.â€ He is also the accomplished childrenâ€™s book writer behind the Hank Zipzer series, and he and his co-author Lin Oliver have together penned 40 kidsâ€™ novels.
	

	Gagerman and Waller are longtime writing partners whose Blacklist feature spec â€œSearch Partyâ€ was produced by Universal and starred Adam Pally and Alison Brie.

	Deadline broke the news.

schema.headline: Henry Winkler to Star in Legal Comedy â€˜Last Chance Lawyerâ€™ in Works at NBC

title: Music Industry Moves: Universal Music Partners With NVIDIA on AI Music-Discovery, More
description: Universal Music Group, which has taken a leadership role in industry relations with AI businesses and creators, has announced a collaboration with N
body:
Universal Music Group, which has taken a leadership role in industry relations with AI businesses and creators, has announced a collaboration with NVIDIA to pioneer what it describes as responsible AI for music discovery, creation, and engagement leveraging the platformâ€™s AI infrastructure and UMGâ€™s massive music catalog.

	According to the announcement, the two companies will undertake collaborative research and development to promote shared objectives of advancing human music creation and rightsholder compensation; and will utlize Â AI to â€œelevate discovery, engagement and consumption beyond current constructs of search and personalization. Further, the companies will pursue new approaches to leverage AI in order to protect artistsâ€™ work and ensure proper attribution of music-based content.â€
	

	As part of this effort, the two companies are extending the NVIDIA Music Flamingo model to enhance fansâ€™ music discovery by processing full-length tracks to capture harmony, structure, timbre, lyrics, and cultural context. Goals also include to enhance fan engagement and encourage artists to use creation tools.


	UMG chairman-CEO Lucian Grainge says, â€œWeâ€™re excited to establish this ground-breaking strategic relationship which unites the worldâ€™s leading technology company with the worldâ€™s leading music company in a shared mission to harness revolutionary AI technology to dramatically advance the interests of the creative community and the role of music in global culture. We eagerly embrace the opportunities that AI presents, and the fact that NVIDIA is choosing to take a leadership position in the tech industry in their commitment to responsible AI principles is critically important.â€
	

	â€œWeâ€™re entering an era where a music catalog can be explored like an intelligent universe â€” conversational, contextual, and genuinely interactiveâ€, said Richard Kerris, NVIDIA VP/GM of Media. â€œBy extending NVIDIAâ€™s Music Flamingo with UMGâ€™s unmatched catalog and creative ecosystem, weâ€™re going to change how fans discover, understand, and engage with music on a global scale. And weâ€™ll do it the right way: responsibly, with safeguards that protect artistsâ€™ work, ensure attribution, and respect copyright.â€

	+ Independent publishing and neighboring rights powerhouse Peermusic has promoted Paul Smelt to chief operating officer, CEO Mary Megan Peer announced. In the newly created role, Smelt will oversee the administration of the companyâ€™s publishing (copyright and royalties) and neighboring rights (repertoire and distributions) for from its Amsterdam office and will report to the CEO.

	Smelt was previously COO of Peermusic Neighbouring Rights and joined the company when it acquired Global Master Rights, the neighboring rights company he co-founded with Erik Veerman (who is now managing director of Peermusic Neighboring Rights). Earlier, he co-founded Global Master Rights in 2014 and worked at neighboring rights organization SENA.

	Mary Megan Peer commented: â€œPaul has been crucial in the integration of the three neighboring rights companies we acquired in 2020 as their COO. We look forward to his continued success as he takes on this role in supporting our publishing operations as well.â€

	+ ASCAP has promoted Hayley Dukes to senior VP of licensing. In her new role she will continue to report to the companyâ€™s head of licensing Stephanie Ruyle. She joined ASCAP in 2020 after roles at AMC Networks and HBO.

	â€œHayleyâ€™s deep knowledge of audiovisual industry operations has made her a key player on the ASCAP licensing team. Iâ€™m looking forward to working further with her as we continue to respond to licensee needs in the evolving media landscape while driving fair compensation for ASCAP members,â€ said Ruyle.

	+ Landr, the Montreal-based AI-powered music production company, has announced the acquisition of Reason Studios, the Stockholm-based company behind the iconic Reason Digital Audio Workstation (DAW) and Reason Rack. The two companies will also establish an Artist Council made up of producers and longtime users of Reason. According to the announcement, Reason Studios will continue to operate as its own brand.
	

	â€œOur vision is to make Reason and the Reason Rack indispensable tools for every producer, regardless of what DAW they use,â€ said Landr CEO Pascal Pilon. â€œWherever music is made, Reason will be there, with its amazing instruments, effects, and iconic analog workflowâ€“enhanced by LANDRâ€™s value-rich creator tools.â€

	+ Big Machine Label Group has promoted Jay Cruze to national director of radio strategy, representing Big Machine Records, the Valory Music Co., and Nashville Harbor Records & Entertainment. He joined Big Machine in 2023 from iHeartMedia, following promotion roles at Average Joes Entertainment and Bigger Picture Group.

	â€œJay was an exceptional addition to Big Machine Records three years ago and his impact has only continued to expand across the entire label group,â€ says EVP/GM Kris Lamb. â€œHis deep understanding of national programming, paired with the trust and relationships he has built at radio, has become a powerful asset for our company.â€

	+ Digital ticket delivery service True Tickets has promoted Ken Lesnik to chief commercial officer and Kirk Mortensen to chief product officer. Since he joined the company in 2019 Lesnik has helped to forge relationships with more than 100 leading arts and cultural organizations across the U.S., Canada, the U.K., and Australia. This includes institutions such as the Royal Ballet and Opera in London, the Toronto Symphony Orchestra, New York City Ballet, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, and Center Theatre Group in Los Angeles. Mortensen had served as head of product since 2022.

	â€œKen and Kirk have helped lead this company through some of its most pivotal chapters,â€ said Matt Zarracina, CEO of True Tickets. â€œTheir contributions have shaped so much of who we are as a company, and their new roles reflect the leadership theyâ€™ve already been demonstrating day in and day out.â€

schema.headline: Music Industry Moves: Universal Music Partners With NVIDIA on AI Music-Discovery, More

title: TMZ Streaming Live, Come Into Our Newsroom and Watch Things Happen!

body:
TMZ Live Stream
                          Come Into Our Office and Watch News Happen!!!

                              January 6, 2026
                            9:44 AM PST
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          We want you to be a part of TMZ, so every weekday, between 9:30 AM and 11:30 AM PT, we take you inside our newsroom via live stream.
      
    
          You never know what you're gonna get ... a big story that breaks, an argument erupts in the room, or someone's just joking around.
      
    
          Your comments are a big part of the stream, and the staff spends a lot of time speaking directly to you. Every day is different!
      
    
          We also use our live stream to produce our "TMZ Live" TV show.

title: NASCAR Commisioner Steve Phelps Resigns After Michael Jordan Antitrust Trial
description:
Steve Phelps
                          NASCAR Commish Steps Away
                          ... Af
body:
Steve Phelps
                          NASCAR Commish Steps Away
                          ... After Texts Leaked in Court
                      
                  
                                                                        Published 
                              January 6, 2026
                            8:33 AM PST
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          NASCARâ€™s first commissioner Steve Phelps announced his resignation Tuesday after 20 years with the racing series â€¦ and a month after his shocking text messages were revealed in a nasty trial.
      
    
          A string of texts between NASCAR executives from 2023 were unsealed during testimony of the recent antitrust trial between two teams -- one being 23XI Racing, owned by Michael Jordan and Denny Hamlin -- and the association.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Phelps in one exchange called Hall of Fame team owner Richard Childress "a stupid redneck" who "needs to be taken out back and flogged" â€¦ he also called Childress an "idiot" and an "ass-clown."
      

          NASCAR ultimately settled the lawsuit â€¦ one day after Bass Pro Shops founder Johnny Morris wrote a letter demanding Phelpsâ€™ removal as commissioner. Phelps will leave the company at the end of the month -- the 2026 season opens Feb. 14 with the Daytona 500.
      
    
          Phelps said in a news release â€¦ "As I embark on new pursuits in sports and other industries, I want to thank the many colleagues, friends and especially the fans that have played such an important and motivational role in my career. Words cannot fully convey the deep appreciation I have for this life-changing experience."
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          NASCAR has not announced any additional leadership or personnel changes following Phelpsâ€™ departure.
      
      
              
          
                          
                Denny Hamlin
              
                          
                Michael Jordan
              
                          
                TMZ Sports

schema.headline: NASCAR Commisioner Steve Phelps Resigns After Michael Jordan Antitrust Trial

title: Machine Gun Kelly & Megan Fox Not Together Romantically Despite Public Outings
description:
MGK & Megan Fox
                          We're Not Back Together ...
                          W
body:
MGK & Megan Fox
                          We're Not Back Together ...
                          We're Just Co-Parents!!!
                      
                  
                                                                        Published 
                              January 6, 2026
                            10:36 AM PST
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Machine Gun Kelly and Megan Fox's recent public outings have sparked rumors of reconciliation ... but sources tell TMZ they're still broken up.
      
    
          Despite being spotted in public several times over the past few months with their daughter, Saga, multiple sources tell us Megan and MGK are currently living separately.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          We're told Megan has the baby full-time and the two are co-parenting as needed.
      

          Sources say Megan and MGK are not in a romantic relationship, and the only time MGK sees or talks to Megan is when he is spending time with their baby girl, who was born in March.
      
    
          The estranged couple actually split just months before Saga's birth. Since then, they've been spotted at the L.A. Zoo, the Getty Center, and on a Costa Rica vacation.
      
    
          They do look good together ... but for now this on-again, off-again situation is definitively OFF.

title: Jelly Roll, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Chrissy Teigen Head Up 'Star Search' Reboot
description:
'Star Search' Reboot
                          Jelly, Chrissy, SMG Join Up to Judge!!!
body:
'Star Search' Reboot
                          Jelly, Chrissy, SMG Join Up to Judge!!!
                      
                  
                                                                        Published 
                              January 6, 2026
                            11:47 AM PST
                                                                            
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Talk about a blast from TVâ€™s past ... "Star Search" is strutting back into the spotlight and has unveiled a celebrity-packed judging panel to officially usher in its shiny reboot.
      
    
          Jelly Roll, Sarah Michelle Gellar, and Chrissy Teigen are officially locked in as judges -- with the reboot premiering January 20 on Netflix, which will shake things up with real-time viewer voting that lets fans help decide which contestants move forward.
      
    
          This isnâ€™t your run-of-the-mill talent show either -- during its original run from '83 to '95, "Star Search" helped launch the careers of Britney Spears, BeyoncÃ©, Justin Timberlake, Adam Sandler and many more.
      
    
          Netflix is leaning all the way in with the reboot, promising in the logline the talent is bigger than ever ... and the stakes have never been higher.
      
    
          And yeah -- that judging panel checks all the boxes. Oneâ€™s a chart-topping rapper, another ruled pop culture TV for years, and the third is a model-turned-media powerhouse -- with Anthony Anderson running the show when it lands on Netflix January 20.
